description: From Middle French patriarcat, from Old French patriarcat, from Medieval Latin patriarchatus, from Ancient Greek πατριάρχης (patriárkhēs, “patriarch”); surface analysis patriarch +‎ -ate.

entries.meaning: (Christianity) The term of office of a Christian patriarch.
examples: The patriarchate of Pope John Paul II as Patriarch of the West was more than 25 years.

entries.meaning: The office or ecclesial jurisdiction of such a patriarch.
examples: The Patriarchate of Constantinople has primacy over the whole of the Orthodox world.

entries.meaning: The office-space occupied by a patriarch and his staff.
examples: The Latin patriarchate in Jerusalem is, by modern standards, a very cramped space.
